original_title: Sri Lanka customs confiscates 9,500 kilos of black gram
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka Customs has confiscated 9,500 kilos of black gram (undu) with an estimated market value of 19,000,000 rupees.

“One hundred and ninety-eight barrels were brought down from Singapore by am importer from Angoda, who declared to Customs that the goods were 8,910 kilos of calcium carbonate,” Superintendent of Customs, Nimal Samarathunga, told reporters.
When investigated, the containers were found to contain undu underneath powder.
In addition to the undu, Sri Lanka Customs also confiscated 34 bags of chickpea (ka-da-la) weighing 120 kilos.
“To bring undu, you must get permission, and they did not do this,” Samarathunga said. “Had this not been found by customs, it would have resulted in a 2.8 billion loss to the Sri Lankan government.”
Undu, or ulundu, is the key ingredient of thosai and vadai, popular foods in the country.
Chickpeas are taxed at 5 rupees a kilo according to rates listed on the Customs website.
Economists have increasingly started to point out that Sri Lanka is no longer an ‘open economy,’ amid high and suddenly changed border taxes.
Sri Lanka has high and regressive border taxes and licensing on foods due to economic nationalism, despite stunting and malnutrition of children. (Colombo/Nov22/2023)
